Some unkind and unjust words have been thrown at the 2019 remake of Aladdin, and I just want to clear a couple of things up and apologize on behalf of white people everywhere.   There will necessarily be spoilers for reasons that will become clear, so if you haven't seen the movie please dodge this review.  First of all, I identified with the 1992 movie and preferred it over the original Lion King, even though the nineties Lion King made more money and was more widely acclaimed than the nineties Aladdin.  That means that I had a lot more at stake in trying to get emotionally invested in the 2019 remake of Aladdin than in the 2019 remake of the Lion King.  I didn't like the new Lion King at all, even though I really tried to.  I loved the new Aladdin.
   The most prevalent word that was thrown at the 2019 Aladdin remake was ‘unnecessary.'  Back in the nineties all of these Disney movies were almost entirely white washed.  For the remake by contrast, nearly all of the major roles went to the appropriate and historical races they ought to have gone to.  And so on that ideal alone, the new movie stands as a testament to how far we've come as a human species since the nineties, which simply wasn't all that long ago.  It says a lot that the roles for these remakes no longer go to the heart throb from Home Improvement or the love interest from Full House anymore.  Now they go to real non-white actors in Hollywood who have been in real and successful movies and who in all reality have just as much charisma as the original white actors from these original movies.   When Donald Glover reprises Jonathan Taylor Thomas and Mathew freaking Broderick (the whitest Lion King that ever did Lion), the limitation that makes Glover's performance fall flat is the animation choices of a white guy, namely Happy Hogan's John Favreau, not any failing of Donald Glover's acting.  And likewise, when Mena Massoud dances or gives that sly smile to Jasmine, he's got miles of soul and charm that Dj Tanner's love interest could never have dreamt of translating to the silver screen.  Sorry white people, but facts are facts. 
     This actually is exactly what makes Will Smith's Genie casting make sense.  I'm not saying that it couldn't have gone to a white guy, but if it did, it would probably need to go to a real Jewish white guy instead of an ‘Honorary Jew.'  Everybody lauds Robin William's performance as the thing that caused the original movie to transcend traditional benchmarks, but let's all just go ahead and stick to those benchmarks for just a moment.  The Genie needs to go to someone so world wise and who is such an old soul that big names like Will Smith or Robin Williams are the only names that even remotely make sense.  I'm not saying that recasting the entire cast with racially appropriate actors will win every time in my book, because the 2019 Lion King remake gets about a 20% rating from me, but it's a really good start.  
     And I'm just going to go ahead and say it, making the statement that Will Smith can't sing in 2019 is just distasteful and racist at this point, and when you see review after review of top critics saying that Will Smith can't sing it shows a person that racism is still alive and well in this day and age.  I would venture to guess that there is a certain white rapper that would like to have a word with you all about your backwards views of the world.  Just because Will Smith doesn't sing the way you want him to doesn't mean he doesn't have a talent for singing.  When he raps about his kids in his platinum album that you all never achieved, that in my book is just as poignant as any aria from Josh Groban and it doesn't matter to me at all who can hit what note.  Singing is singing and talent is talent, and so therefore rapping is singing and beat-boxing is talent, and the color that divergent styles add to music is exactly what makes the world such a beautiful place to live in.  The problem might not even be that the movie was bad, the problem for some of these reviewers might be that an Arabic story about Arabian Knights told by white people and sung about by white people is no longer told by white people and no longer sung about by white people and that rubs white people the wrong way.  
     As for how Will Smith holistically approached the role, forgoing William's manic for his own laid back style made him a new Genie for a new generation to love and a previous generation to appreciate, whereas if he had tried to sing Robin William's songs it would have been a mistake right out of the gate.  In every other way Smith chose to honor Robin William's turn while adding his own personality and whit to the role instead of completely recasting the character.  These turned out to be perfect choices, by Smith and by Disney. 
    The second ideal that the movie stands on is on the idea of a female becoming a Sultan.  It helps for one to realize that the faction of Islam that would ever accept a female as a Sultan is at least as much of a fringe faction of Islam as the faction that decided it would be a good idea to fling Aeroplanes at buildings with white people still inside of the aeroplanes and the buildings.  That makes Disney's statement about strong female leads a bold statement about human decency and achievement, and I found at least a couple of the tonal notes of Aladdin to be just as poignant as Marvel's Black Panther in hitting a relevant and applaudable (and plausible) resonance with today's audience.  And I just have to say as a white person that if I can learn even a little bit about Arabic culture in a movie like Aladdin, or about Black American or African culture in a movie like Black Panther, then white people can sit and complain about those sorts of movies all day and they won't move me at all.  
   This movie is in good taste, and in good company for that reason alone.  The biggest new musical number that they added that everyone says they hated is a song about just exactly that; about an Arabic woman who refuses to stay silent.  And I for one love the song and I don't see what's wrong with it.   In just a few moments of brilliant dialogue Naomi Scott manages to move us to understand, even for just a moment what it might be like to be Arabic woman whose life is put in danger just because of the gender she was born with. And believe me when I say, I am just as tired as everyone else at the prospect of feminist idealism and social justice being flung on the top of every movie for good measure.  I was ready to complain along with everyone else about how kubrickian that theme seems at this point and why it would be needful to add it to Aladdin when the original Aladdin was already a feminist's dream movie.  But at the end of the day it works, and if that's all you can say about Aladdin in 2019, then this movie was a rousting success in my book.  
      Maybe these Disney remakes aren't the thing that is unnecessary, maybe what is unnecessary is the entire site and staff of Rotten Tomatoes and its undying need to compare every new movie to old ways of thinking and old movies.  I know we're in this mode of retreading every old idea, and that mode definitely has its downsides, but at the end of the day, young people need to see the value in antiquated ideas, and old people need to see the diamonds in the rough that are placed in these new movies for what they are.  If that idealism fails then the rift between the generations will grow ever larger, and human understanding will diminish.  These new ideas from a new generation, these gems that can be found in re-released movies, these diamonds in the rough are far from unnecessary.  They are necessary.
    Disney's new narration of Aladdin gives the world a new and better narrative of what it means to be American in 2019.  It gives a pretty smashing narrative of what it means to be Arabic in 2019, for that matter. And, most telling, far from being "a whole old world," that is exactly the note that Disney was able to hit that causes 2019's Aladdin to smash old benchmarks and become "a whole new world," and a new voice for a new generation of movie goers.

This is yet another attempt by disney to remake beloved classics that don't need to be remade, and after viewing this film, I can safely say that the animated original is way better than this remake, and it is the only Aladdin movie that we will ever need. Let's get into the nitty gritty then, shall we. First off, the runtime for this movie is just to long and they constantly have to keep making up new things to increase the runtime, but this really didn't need that extra content that was added in, it became very boring. The performances were all weak, save Naomi Scott who is really trying in this movie and she is almost as good in this film as her animated self in the original movie. Mena Massoud was just too full of himself in this role and he felt overbearing, he just didn't do the character of Aladdin justice at all. Marwan Kenzari was pretty bad in this movie, he was not menacing at all and the evil parts of his character felt very forced and unnatural, he even said some dumb things that just sucked, he wasn't so bad that he ticked me off, but he was really laughable in this film. Iago and Raja were really wasted in this film, they both did nothing of any significance except preview what the Lion King remake looks like, great CGI, but emotionless characters who don't belong anywhere but the animated world. Will Smith as the genie was surprisingly good, when he was blue and flying, he tried too much to be Robin Williams, but when he was pretending to be a human, he was the most entertaining part of this film. Smith also has a good singing voice and he delivers on the Arabian Nights song in the beginning. The songs in this movie all feel out of place and like they are interrupting the story, they were all done so much better in the original. Ultimately, this is a film of mediocrity, it is too long, has some terrible dialogue and performances, and most of the songs in this movie ruin the beloved ones in the original. The saving graces in this film are Naomi Scott, and Will Smith, this movie would be nothing without them. If you hold the original near and dear to your heart, then you will not like this remake, I recommend to skip over this one, but if your into over the top musicals with terrible characters, than be my guest. As for me, I don't think that I will ever have any desire to rewatch this at all, it was very disappointing and boring, and it kind of ruined a beloved movie of mine that I grew up with.

Review:
‘Aladdin' is an American musical-fantasy film directed by Guy Ritchie. It is a live-action adaptation of Disney's 1992 animated film of the same name. Upon watching this movie, I was skeptical due to the fact I didn't believe they would be able to capture the same magic that the 1992 animated film had. At times this movie really shined, but that didn't happen until the second and third act. I was almost ready to turn the movie off after the first act. It didn't grasp your attention at all, and everything was lackluster and boring.
The film follows Aladdin (Mena Massoud) a street urchin, as he falls in love with Princess Jasmine (Naomi Scott) befriends a wish-granting Genie (Will Smith) and battles the wicked Jafar (Marwan Kenzari).
This movie didn't take off at all until Will Smith was introduced. His charisma and funny attitude towards Aladdin and certain situations were amazing. He stole every scene he was in and basically saved this movie from a bad review. I could care less about the other characters in this movie aside from Genie, Aladdin and Jasmine. Jaffar, who is supposed to be this big bad was not scary or menacing at all and I do believe that is because the actor did not have what it takes to pull the character off. It just fell flat. I really enjoyed Mena Massoud and Naomi Scott's portrayal as Aladdin and Jasmine. Their chemistry together was real, and it felt like the characters could come off the screen and live in the real world. However, as I said the rest of the characters fell short and you don't care what happens or even remember who they are when they come on screen another time.
I told myself I would not be comparing this to the 1992 animated film, but it's hard not to compare Genies. Will Smith did a great job in this movie and took on what was thought to be an impossible role and made it his own. I did still find myself missing Robin Williams when it came to the music numbers. I will say what I liked the most with this movie is the ending. Man did it stick the landing on that ending. It made you feel so many emotions. Now, I'm not one to complain about CGI when it's from a movie that has a low budget such as an Indie film or even a B-rate production company. When it's Disney and you see things like Marvel or The Lion King you know they can produce good CGI and this movie fell short in that aspect.
Overall, this movie fell hard in the first act and was lucky people stuck around for the second and third because the movie does a 180 turn and takes off. If you want a fun adventure film this one will do that for sure, and if you're a fan of the original this one keeps its core values as well as throwing in some fresh elements.
3/5

They doubled the run time of the film, it was so painfully slow, it felt like it was never going to end; filling it with unnecessary dialogue, unnecessary new characters, and added terribly written new songs to fit the new storyline. This wasn't Aladdin's story, with all of the changes that directly affected the plot, they should have changed the films name to Jasmine.

Aladdin is supposed to be charming, it seemed as though there wasnt any chemistry between him amd Jasmine; the only reason she married him was because he supported her rule as Sultan. 

 Also, there will never be another Robin Williams, but it would have been nice if they picked a genie that actually had a range of voices and comedic impressions. Will Smith wasn't terrible, he did the best with what he had, but he's incapable of bringing even a fraction of what Robin brought to the role.

Aladdin was Disneys 2nd live-action film after Dumbo. While it was not nearly as anticipated like The Lion King was, I found myself liking Aladdin much more for numerous reasons. 

Firstly, the overall story played a major role! While most Disney live-action films tend to be exactly the same for audiences, Aladdin had plenty of fresh content to make the film worth seeing. One of the changes I especially enjoyed was the changes made to Jasmine character. She is given a lot more dept and much more to do. One of the weaker aspects of the film was Jafar.  His character was overall weak and lacked the sinister feeling he had in the original. 

Secondly, Will Smith as the Genie! The Genie was heavily criticized in the marketing for the film. However, he respected Robin and made the character his own. He sparks plenty of humor and the "Friend Like Me" aspect was truly a pleasure to look at. He was overall funny and filled with endless energy. 

Thirdly, Mena Massoud was an excellent choice for Aladdin! Just as most people, myself included, I was not sure about how I felt about Mena portraying the charming street rat. However, he proved me wrong and did it in an excellent style. Also, another great aspect I would method would be Naomi Scott as the lovely Jasmine. She was excellent and was given so much life by her. Jasmine new song Speechless was a delight to hear. 

In conclusion, I felt myself smiling half of the time. The whole movie, besides Jafar, was a win for me. Aladdin may not be my favorite classic (The Lion King is which is why the remake was so disappointing) but this is for sure my favorite live-action to date!

I think the inherent danger Disney runs the risk of whenever they do a remake on one of their classics is that people come in with high standards and expectations. Watching the film, I personally believed that when I put the original aside and judged the film solely by its own merits, I thought it was amazing. The costumes were on point, the actors were a breath of fresh air, and I honestly believe that Will Smith stole the show. If there is one thing I absolutely appreciated in Will Smith's performance of the Genie, it was that he didn't try to do a caricature of Robin Williams playing Genie; he came in with his own take on the character. Well done! I look forward to buying this one on dvd.

I have 1001 issues with this film: with the direction, the script, the CGI, and probably also with a lot of other things, but I had only 3 wishes to know in which aspects I have issues, and I'm not as lucky as Aladdin to have Will Smith as a friend who breaks the rules for him.

P.S. Speechless must win the Oscar for best original song!

Wildly surpassed my expectations-mostly because I had none. I don't mean that in a bad way, just that this wasn't a movie on my summer radar if you know what I mean. But after seeing it twice, I can verfifiably say I not only enjoyed it for its fun and enthusiastic take on the story, but was seriously impressed by the feminist tone the movie took. Princess Jasmine went from a pretty passive character, controlled by the will's of the men in her life, to someone who has desires, goals, and doesn't wait for someone to let her do anything. As the song goes, Jasmine speaks up and becomes the Sulton without anyone allowing her to. Because she is right for the role, she steps up as the leader of her people to protect them from Jafar before her father acknowledges her strenght and leadership qualities by giving her his ring and bestowign Sulton-hood upon her, or however that offically goes. Naomi Scott won a gold medal for feminist role-models in my book. It was also a fun watch for the songs and dances. Will Smith did an admirable job filling some of the film world's most roomy footwear. Aladdin himself was great if outshone a bit by Jasmine in this one in my opinion, but all in all it was a fun watch and a great step in the right direction for representing disney princesses as more empowered leaders.
